part_of: Hundred Years' War (as a peripheral conflict)

causes: Territorial disputes between Peter I of Castile and Peter IV of Aragon.
Dynastic and political rivalry between Castile and Aragon over influence in the Mediterranean and Iberian Peninsula.
Aragonese support for Henry of Trastámara’s claim to the Castilian throne, leading to internal Castilian struggles.
Impact of the broader Hundred Years' War, as Castile and Aragon aligned with opposing factions (England and France).
events_leading_up_to_war: Tensions escalated over control of border territories such as Valencia, Murcia, and Catalonia.
Peter I of Castile's expansionist policies antagonized Aragon.
Aragonese naval actions against Castilian trade and raids on coastal settlements.

result.general: Inconclusive, but Castile emerged as the dominant power in Iberia.

treaties.name: Peace of Almazán
terms: Aragon renounced claims to Castilian lands in Murcia.
End of direct hostilities, but dynastic rivalries persisted.
Strengthened the position of Henry of Trastámara, later King of Castile.

territorial_changes: Aragon retained control over key Mediterranean trade routes.
Castile consolidated power in Murcia and central Iberia.

Castile: Peter I of Castile ('Peter the Cruel')
Du Guesclin (French mercenary later supporting Henry of Trastámara)
Aragon: Peter IV of Aragon ('Peter the Ceremonious')
Hugh de Calveley (English mercenary in Aragonese service)

Castile.navy: Large fleet capable of challenging Aragonese dominance in the Mediterranean
Castile.tactics: Strong use of mercenaries, rapid territorial raids

Aragon.navy: One of the most powerful navies in the Mediterranean
Aragon.tactics: Defensive warfare, fortified strongholds, naval superiority

Castile.dead_and_wounded: Tens of thousands, exacerbated by internal civil strife

Aragon.dead_and_wounded: Severe losses in Catalonia and Valencia due to Castilian invasions

major_battles.name: Siege of Tarazona
major_battles.description: Castilian forces laid siege to the Aragonese-held city of Tarazona. The city fell after heavy fighting.

major_battles.name: Battle of Nájera
major_battles.description: Clash between Peter I of Castile and Henry of Trastámara, with the latter backed by French forces.
major_battles.outcome: Castilian victory, but Peter I failed to fully consolidate power.

major_battles.name: Naval Battle of Barcelona
major_battles.description: A major naval engagement between Castilian and Aragonese fleets off the coast of Barcelona.
major_battles.outcome: Aragonese victory; Castile's naval ambitions in the Mediterranean weakened.

texts.name: Chronicles of Peter IV of Aragon
texts.author: Peter IV himself
texts.details: Aragonese perspective on the war, portraying Castile as the aggressor.

texts.name: Castilian Royal Annals
texts.author: Anonymous Castilian historian
texts.details: Chronicles the war as a just struggle for Castilian supremacy.

archaeological_evidence.description: Ruins of border castles and siege works in Catalonia and Murcia.
Castilian swords, Aragonese crossbows, and remnants of naval artillery from the Battle of Barcelona.

political: Castile emerged stronger, laying the groundwork for future Spanish unification.
Aragon maintained independence but lost influence over Castilian territories.
long_term_effects: Strengthened Henry of Trastámara, leading to his eventual rule as Henry II of Castile.
Weakened Peter I of Castile, who was later assassinated in 1369.
Set the stage for later Iberian conflicts between Castile and Aragon.

military: Demonstrated the importance of mercenary forces in medieval warfare.
Naval battles showcased early Mediterranean naval tactics.
political: Deepened the rivalry between Castile and Aragon.
Influenced alliances in the Hundred Years' War.
cultural: Led to a wave of historical chronicles detailing the conflict.
Impacted Spanish literature and folklore, portraying Peter I as either 'the Cruel' or 'the Just'.
